content:
Dear Lean Users,

We DeLTA Lab (at Simon Fraser University) are building foundational tools to support mathematicians working on formal mathematics.

We are excited to introduce Lean Finder, a semantic search engine for Lean that understands latent intents behind your queries.

You can try Lean Finder in two ways:

  1. Web Service: With beautifully rendered LaTeX and code: https://leanfinder.github.io/
  2. Zulip Chat: You can simply ping our chatbot: @leanfinder + your inquiry.

Lean Finder supports four types of input:

  • Informalized statement – A full or partial natural-language description of the statement you’re looking for.
  • User question – Ask in your own words, e.g., “Is there code for …” · “Why does this give an error …” · “How to define or derive instances …” · “How to finish or shorten proofs …” · “How to apply this lemma or theorem …”
  • Proof state – Paste your current state directly from VS Code.
  • Statement definition – Provide any fragment or complete definition.

Finally, our web service includes feedback tools. Please vote or upvote retrievals you find useful. Your feedback directly helps us improve Lean Finder, making it an even more powerful resource for the Lean and Zulip communities.

Thank you!

Sincerely,
Wuyang

Some examples of use cases:

@leanfinder Let L/K be a field extension and let x, y ∈ L be algebraic elements over K with the same minimal polynomial. Then the K-algebra isomorphism algEquiv between the simple field extensions K(x) and K(y) maps the generator x of K(x) to the generator y of K(y); i.e. algEquiv(x) = y.

Here’s what I found:

  • theorem minpoly.algEquiv_apply {x y : L} (hx : IsAlgebraic K x) (h_mp : minpoly K x = minpoly K y) : algEquiv hx h_mp (AdjoinSimple.gen K x) = AdjoinSimple.gen K y := by have hy : IsAlgebraic K y := ⟨minpoly K x, ne_zero hx.isIntegral, (h_mp ▸ aeval _ _)⟩ rw [algEquiv, trans_apply, ← adjoinRootEquivAdjoin_apply_root K hx.isIntegral, symm_apply_apply, trans_apply, AdjoinRoot.algEquivOfEq_apply_root, adjoinRootEquivAdjoin_apply_root K hy.isIntegral] "Let L/KL/KL/K be a field extension and let x,y∈Lx, y \in Lx,y∈L be algebraic elements over KKK with the same minimal polynomial. Then the KKK-algebra isomorphism algEquiv\text{algEquiv}algEquiv between the simple field extensions K(x)K(x)K(x) and K(y)K(y)K(y) maps the generator xxx of K(x)K(x)K(x) to the generator yyy of K(y)K(y)K(y), i.e.,
    algEquiv(x)=y.\text{algEquiv}(x) = y.algEquiv(x)=y." (score: 0.861)

  • theorem algEquiv_apply {x y : L} (hx : IsAlgebraic K x) (h_mp : minpoly K x = minpoly K y) : algEquiv hx h_mp (AdjoinSimple.gen K x) = AdjoinSimple.gen K y := by have hy : IsAlgebraic K y := ⟨minpoly K x, ne_zero hx.isIntegral, (h_mp ▸ aeval _ _)⟩ rw [algEquiv, trans_apply, ← adjoinRootEquivAdjoin_apply_root K hx.isIntegral, symm_apply_apply, trans_apply, AdjoinRoot.algEquivOfEq_apply_root, adjoinRootEquivAdjoin_apply_root K hy.isIntegral] "Let L/KL/KL/K be a field extension and let x,y∈Lx, y \in Lx,y∈L be algebraic elements over KKK with the same minimal polynomial. Then the KKK-algebra isomorphism algEquiv\text{algEquiv}algEquiv between the simple field extensions K(x)K(x)K(x) and K(y)K(y)K(y) maps the generator xxx of K(x)K(x)K(x) to the generator yyy of K(y)K(y)K(y), i.e., algEquiv(x)=y.\text{algEquiv}(x) = y.algEquiv(x)=y." (score: 0.859)

  • /-- The canonical algEquiv between K⟮x⟯and K⟮y⟯, sending x to y, where x and y have
    the same minimal polynomial over K. -/ noncomputable def algEquiv {x y : L} (hx : IsAlgebraic K x) (h_mp : minpoly K x = minpoly K y) : K⟮x⟯ ≃ₐ[K] K⟮y⟯ := by have hy : IsAlgebraic K y := ⟨minpoly K x, ne_zero hx.isIntegral, (h_mp ▸ aeval _ _)⟩ exact AlgEquiv.trans (adjoinRootEquivAdjoin K hx.isIntegral).symm (AlgEquiv.trans (AdjoinRoot.algEquivOfEq (ne_zero hx.isIntegral) h_mp) (adjoinRootEquivAdjoin K hy.isIntegral))     "Let L/KL/KL/K be a field extension and let x,y∈Lx, y \in Lx,y∈L be algebraic elements over KKK with the same minimal polynomial. Then there exists a canonical KKK-algebra isomorphism between the simple field extensions K(x)K(x)K(x) and K(y)K(y)K(y) that maps xxx to yyy." (score: 0.842)

  • definition minpoly.algEquiv {x y : L} (hx : IsAlgebraic K x) (h_mp : minpoly K x = minpoly K y) : K⟮x⟯ ≃ₐ[K] K⟮y⟯ := by have hy : IsAlgebraic K y := ⟨minpoly K x, ne_zero hx.isIntegral, (h_mp ▸ aeval _ _)⟩ exact AlgEquiv.trans (adjoinRootEquivAdjoin K hx.isIntegral).symm (AlgEquiv.trans (AdjoinRoot.algEquivOfEq (ne_zero hx.isIntegral) h_mp) (adjoinRootEquivAdjoin K hy.isIntegral)) "Given a field extension L/KL/KL/K and two elements x,y∈Lx, y \in Lx,y∈L that are algebraic over KKK with the same minimal polynomial, there exists a KKK-algebra isomorphism between the intermediate fields K(x)K(x)K(x) and K(y)K(y)K(y). This isomorphism maps the generator xxx of K(x)K(x)K(x) to the generator yyy of K(y)K(y)K(y)." (score: 0.834)

  • theorem algEquivOfEq_apply_root {p q : K[X]} (hp : p ≠ 0) (h_eq : p = q) : algEquivOfEq hp h_eq (root p) = root q := by rw [← coe_algHom, algEquivOfEq_toAlgHom, liftHom_root] "Let KKK be a field and let p,q∈K[X]p, q \in K[X]p,q∈K[X] be nonzero polynomials such that p=qp = qp=q. The algebra isomorphism algEquivOfEq\text{algEquivOfEq}algEquivOfEq from AdjoinRoot p\text{AdjoinRoot}\,pAdjoinRootp to AdjoinRoot q\text{AdjoinRoot}\,qAdjoinRootq maps the adjoined root of ppp to the adjoined root of qqq, i.e., algEquivOfEq hp heq(root p)=root q.\text{algEquivOfEq}\,h_p\,h_{eq}(\text{root}\,p) = \text{root}\,q.algEquivOfEqhp​heq​(rootp)=rootq." (score: 0.791)

  • theorem minpoly.exists_algEquiv_of_root [Normal K L] {x y : L} (hy : IsAlgebraic K y) (h_ev : (Polynomial.aeval x) (minpoly K y) = 0) : ∃ σ : L ≃ₐ[K] L, σ x = y := by have hx : IsAlgebraic K x := ⟨minpoly K y, ne_zero hy.isIntegral, h_ev⟩ set f : K⟮x⟯ ≃ₐ[K] K⟮y⟯ := algEquiv hx (eq_of_root hy h_ev) have hxy : (liftNormal f L) ((algebraMap (↥K⟮x⟯) L) (AdjoinSimple.gen K x)) = y := by rw [liftNormal_commutes f L, algEquiv_apply, AdjoinSimple.algebraMap_gen K y] exact ⟨(liftNormal f L), hxy⟩ "Let L/KL/KL/K be a normal field extension, and let x,y∈Lx, y \in Lx,y∈L be elements such that yyy is algebraic over KKK and xxx is a root of the minimal polynomial of yyy over KKK. Then there exists a KKK-algebra automorphism σ:L→L\sigma: L \to Lσ:L→L such that σ(x)=y\sigma(x) = yσ(x)=y." (score: 0.790)

  • theorem exists_algEquiv_of_root [Normal K L] {x y : L} (hy : IsAlgebraic K y) (h_ev : (Polynomial.aeval x) (minpoly K y) = 0) : ∃ σ : L ≃ₐ[K] L, σ x = y := by have hx : IsAlgebraic K x := ⟨minpoly K y, ne_zero hy.isIntegral, h_ev⟩ set f : K⟮x⟯ ≃ₐ[K] K⟮y⟯ := algEquiv hx (eq_of_root hy h_ev) have hxy : (liftNormal f L) ((algebraMap (↥K⟮x⟯) L) (AdjoinSimple.gen K x)) = y := by rw [liftNormal_commutes f L, algEquiv_apply, AdjoinSimple.algebraMap_gen K y] exact ⟨(liftNormal f L), hxy⟩ "Let L/KL/KL/K be a normal field extension, and let x,y∈Lx, y \in Lx,y∈L be algebraic over KKK. If xxx is a root of the minimal polynomial of yyy over KKK, then there exists a KKK-algebra isomorphism σ:L≃L\sigma: L \simeq Lσ:L≃L such that σ(x)=y\sigma(x) = yσ(x)=y. This means xxx and yyy are Galois conjugates." (score: 0.789)

  • theorem minpoly.exists_algEquiv_of_root' [Normal K L] {x y : L} (hy : IsAlgebraic K y) (h_ev : (Polynomial.aeval x) (minpoly K y) = 0) : ∃ σ : L ≃ₐ[K] L, σ y = x := by obtain ⟨σ, hσ⟩ := exists_algEquiv_of_root hy h_ev use σ.symm rw [← hσ, symm_apply_apply] "Let L/KL/KL/K be a normal field extension, and let x,y∈Lx, y \in Lx,y∈L be elements such that yyy is algebraic over KKK and xxx is a root of the minimal polynomial of yyy over KKK. Then there exists a KKK-algebra automorphism σ:L→L\sigma: L \to Lσ:L→L such that σ(y)=x\sigma(y) = xσ(y)=x." (score: 0.782)

  • theorem AdjoinRoot.algEquivOfEq_apply_root {p q : K[X]} (hp : p ≠ 0) (h_eq : p = q) : algEquivOfEq hp h_eq (root p) = root q := by rw [← coe_algHom, algEquivOfEq_toAlgHom, liftHom_root] "Let KKK be a field and let p,q∈K[X]p, q \in K[X]p,q∈K[X] be nonzero polynomials such that p=qp = qp=q. The algebra isomorphism algEquivOfEq\text{algEquivOfEq}algEquivOfEq from AdjoinRoot p\text{AdjoinRoot}\,pAdjoinRootp to AdjoinRoot q\text{AdjoinRoot}\,qAdjoinRootq maps the adjoined root of ppp to the adjoined root of qqq, i.e.,
    algEquivOfEq hp heq(root p)=root q.\text{algEquivOfEq}\,h_p\,h_{eq}(\text{root}\,p) = \text{root}\,q.algEquivOfEqhp​heq​(rootp)=rootq." (score: 0.780)

  • theorem algEquivOfAssociated_apply_root {p q : K[X]} (hp : p ≠ 0) (hpq : Associated p q) : algEquivOfAssociated hp hpq (root p) = root q := by rw [← coe_algHom, algEquivOfAssociated_toAlgHom, liftHom_root] "Let KKK be a field and let p,q∈K[X]p, q \in K[X]p,q∈K[X] be nonzero associated polynomials. If AdjoinRoot⁡p≃AdjoinRoot⁡q\operatorname{AdjoinRoot} p \simeq \operatorname{AdjoinRoot} qAdjoinRootp≃AdjoinRootq is an algebra equivalence, then the adjoined root root⁡p\operatorname{root}_prootp​ of ppp is mapped to the adjoined root root⁡q\operatorname{root}_qrootq​ of qqq under this equivalence." (score: 0.780)

@leanfinder K : Type u_1
E : Type u_2
inst✝ : RCLike K
z✝ z : K
⊢ |re z| ≤ ‖z‖
Transform the goal from proving that the absolute value of the real part of a complex number is less than or equal to its norm, to proving that the square of the real part is less than or equal to the squared norm of the number.

Here’s what I found:

  • theorem RCLike.abs_re_le_norm (z : K) : |re z| ≤ ‖z‖ := by rw [mul_self_le_mul_self_iff (abs_nonneg _) (norm_nonneg _), abs_mul_abs_self, mul_self_norm] apply re_sq_le_normSq "For any element zzz in a real-complex like field KKK (where KKK is either R\mathbb{R}R or C\mathbb{C}C), the absolute value of its real part is bounded by its norm, i.e., ∣Re z∣≤∥z∥|\text{Re } z| \leq \|z\|∣Re z∣≤∥z∥." (score: 0.797)

  • theorem RCLike.normSq_eq_def' (z : K) : normSq z = ‖z‖ ^ 2 := norm_sq_eq_def.symm "For any element zzz in an RCLike field KKK (which is either R\mathbb{R}R or C\mathbb{C}C), the squared norm normSq(z)\text{normSq}(z)normSq(z) equals the square of its norm, i.e.,
    normSq(z)=∥z∥2. \text{normSq}(z) = \|z\|^2. normSq(z)=∥z∥2." (score: 0.793)

  • theorem sq_le_sq : a ^ 2 ≤ b ^ 2 ↔ |a| ≤ |b| := by simpa only [sq_abs] using sq_le_sq₀ (abs_nonneg a) (abs_nonneg b) "For any elements aaa and bbb in a linearly ordered ring α\alphaα, the square of aaa is less than or equal to the square of bbb if and only if the absolute value of aaa is less than or equal to the absolute value of bbb, i.e., a2≤b2↔∣a∣≤∣b∣a^2 \leq b^2 \leftrightarrow |a| \leq |b|a2≤b2↔∣a∣≤∣b∣." (score: 0.791)

  • theorem RCLike.re_le_norm (z : K) : re z ≤ ‖z‖ := (abs_le.1 (abs_re_le_norm z)).2 "For any element zzz in a real-complex like field KKK (where KKK is either R\mathbb{R}R or C\mathbb{C}C), the real part of zzz is bounded by its norm, i.e., Re z≤∥z∥\text{Re } z \leq \|z\|Re z≤∥z∥." (score: 0.790)

  • theorem RCLike.norm_re_le_norm (z : K) : ‖re z‖ ≤ ‖z‖ := abs_re_le_norm z "For any element zzz in a real-complex like field KKK (where KKK is either R\mathbb{R}R or C\mathbb{C}C), the norm of its real part is bounded by its norm, i.e., ∥Re z∥≤∥z∥\|\text{Re } z\| \leq \|z\|∥Re z∥≤∥z∥." (score: 0.790)

  • theorem RCLike.re_sq_le_normSq (z : K) : re z * re z ≤ normSq z := le_add_of_nonneg_right (mul_self_nonneg _) "For any element zzz in a real-complex like field KKK (where KKK is either R\mathbb{R}R or C\mathbb{C}C), the square of its real part is less than or equal to its squared norm, i.e., (Re z)2≤normSq z(\text{Re } z)^2 \leq \text{normSq } z(Re z)2≤normSq z." (score: 0.790)

  • theorem Real.le_sqrt (hx : 0 ≤ x) (hy : 0 ≤ y) : x ≤ √y ↔ x ^ 2 ≤ y := le_iff_le_iff_lt_iff_lt.2 <| sqrt_lt hy hx "For any nonnegative real numbers xxx and yyy, the inequality x≤yx \leq \sqrt{y}x≤y​ holds if and only if x2≤yx^2 \leq yx2≤y." (score: 0.786)

  • theorem sq_abs (a : α) : |a| ^ 2 = a ^ 2 := by simpa only [sq] using abs_mul_abs_self a "For any element aaa in a linearly ordered ring α\alphaα, the square of the absolute value of aaa equals the square of aaa, i.e., ∣a∣2=a2|a|^2 = a^2∣a∣2=a2." (score: 0.786)

  • theorem RCLike.sqrt_normSq_eq_norm {z : K} : √(normSq z) = ‖z‖ := by rw [normSq_eq_def', Real.sqrt_sq (norm_nonneg _)] "For any element zzz in an RCLike field KKK (which is either R\mathbb{R}R or C\mathbb{C}C), the square root of its squared norm equals its norm, i.e.,
    normSq(z)=∥z∥. \sqrt{\text{normSq}(z)} = \|z\|. normSq(z)​=∥z∥." (score: 0.785)

  • theorem RCLike.mul_self_norm (z : K) : ‖z‖ * ‖z‖ = normSq z := by rw [normSq_eq_def', sq] "For any element zzz in an RCLike field KKK (which is either R\mathbb{R}R or C\mathbb{C}C), the product of the norm of zzz with itself equals the squared norm of zzz, i.e.,
    ∥z∥⋅∥z∥=normSq(z). \|z\| \cdot \|z\| = \text{normSq}(z). ∥z∥⋅∥z∥=normSq(z)." (score: 0.779)
@Wuyang Don't cross post

Matthew Ballard said:

Wuyang Don't cross post

No more! I just posted in general and new members. Hope that could be fine.
I have removed your post in #new members. Don't cross post.
Some initial feedback; this output is way too verbose to be suitable for zulip; I suggest following the loogle bot and giving a one-line summary and a link to the webpage.
Showing the proof for each theorem is also very strange, as this is not relevant at all when trying to search for a theorem to apply.

@Eric Wieser Thank you very much for this valuable feedback! It took me some time to integrate this change.
I give an example below. Do you like this format?

@leanfinder Let L/K be a field extension and let x, y ∈ L be algebraic elements over K with the same minimal polynomial. Then the K-algebra isomorphism algEquiv between the simple field extensions K(x) and K(y) maps the generator x of K(x) to the generator y of K(y); i.e. algEquiv(x) = y.

Here’s what I found:

minpoly.algEquiv_apply (score: 0.868)

Let L/KL/KL/K be a field extension and let x,y∈Lx, y \in Lx,y∈L be algebraic elements over KKK with the same minimal polynomial. Then the KKK-algebra isomorphism algEquiv\text{algEquiv}algEquiv between the simple field extensions K(x)K(x)K(x) and K(y)K(y)K(y) maps the generator xxx of K(x)K(x)K(x) to the generator yyy of K(y)K(y)K(y), i.e.,
algEquiv(x)=y.\text{algEquiv}(x) = y.algEquiv(x)=y.

algEquiv_apply (score: 0.865)

Let L/KL/KL/K be a field extension and let x,y∈Lx, y \in Lx,y∈L be algebraic elements over KKK with the same minimal polynomial. Then the KKK-algebra isomorphism algEquiv\text{algEquiv}algEquiv between the simple field extensions K(x)K(x)K(x) and K(y)K(y)K(y) maps the generator xxx of K(x)K(x)K(x) to the generator yyy of K(y)K(y)K(y), i.e., algEquiv(x)=y.\text{algEquiv}(x) = y.algEquiv(x)=y.

minpoly.algEquiv (score: 0.844)

Given a field extension L/KL/KL/K and two elements x,y∈Lx, y \in Lx,y∈L that are algebraic over KKK with the same minimal polynomial, there exists a KKK-algebra isomorphism between the intermediate fields K(x)K(x)K(x) and K(y)K(y)K(y). This isomorphism maps the generator xxx of K(x)K(x)K(x) to the generator yyy of K(y)K(y)K(y).

More Retrievals...

minpoly.exists_algEquiv_of_root (score: 0.798)

Let L/KL/KL/K be a normal field extension, and let x,y∈Lx, y \in Lx,y∈L be elements such that yyy is algebraic over KKK and xxx is a root of the minimal polynomial of yyy over KKK. Then there exists a KKK-algebra automorphism σ:L→L\sigma: L \to Lσ:L→L such that σ(x)=y\sigma(x) = yσ(x)=y.

algEquivOfEq_apply_root (score: 0.797)

Let KKK be a field and let p,q∈K[X]p, q \in K[X]p,q∈K[X] be nonzero polynomials such that p=qp = qp=q. The algebra isomorphism algEquivOfEq\text{algEquivOfEq}algEquivOfEq from AdjoinRoot p\text{AdjoinRoot}\,pAdjoinRootp to AdjoinRoot q\text{AdjoinRoot}\,qAdjoinRootq maps the adjoined root of ppp to the adjoined root of qqq, i.e., algEquivOfEq hp heq(root p)=root q.\text{algEquivOfEq}\,h_p\,h_{eq}(\text{root}\,p) = \text{root}\,q.algEquivOfEqhp​heq​(rootp)=rootq.

exists_algEquiv_of_root (score: 0.795)

Let L/KL/KL/K be a normal field extension, and let x,y∈Lx, y \in Lx,y∈L be algebraic over KKK. If xxx is a root of the minimal polynomial of yyy over KKK, then there exists a KKK-algebra isomorphism σ:L≃L\sigma: L \simeq Lσ:L≃L such that σ(x)=y\sigma(x) = yσ(x)=y. This means xxx and yyy are Galois conjugates.

minpoly.exists_algEquiv_of_root' (score: 0.790)

Let L/KL/KL/K be a normal field extension, and let x,y∈Lx, y \in Lx,y∈L be elements such that yyy is algebraic over KKK and xxx is a root of the minimal polynomial of yyy over KKK. Then there exists a KKK-algebra automorphism σ:L→L\sigma: L \to Lσ:L→L such that σ(y)=x\sigma(y) = xσ(y)=x.

AdjoinRoot.algEquivOfEq_apply_root (score: 0.788)

Let KKK be a field and let p,q∈K[X]p, q \in K[X]p,q∈K[X] be nonzero polynomials such that p=qp = qp=q. The algebra isomorphism algEquivOfEq\text{algEquivOfEq}algEquivOfEq from AdjoinRoot p\text{AdjoinRoot}\,pAdjoinRootp to AdjoinRoot q\text{AdjoinRoot}\,qAdjoinRootq maps the adjoined root of ppp to the adjoined root of qqq, i.e.,
algEquivOfEq hp heq(root p)=root q.\text{algEquivOfEq}\,h_p\,h_{eq}(\text{root}\,p) = \text{root}\,q.algEquivOfEqhp​heq​(rootp)=rootq.

exists_algEquiv_of_root' (score: 0.787)

Let L/KL/KL/K be a normal field extension, and let x,y∈Lx, y \in Lx,y∈L be algebraic over KKK. If xxx is a root of the minimal polynomial of yyy over KKK, then there exists a KKK-algebra isomorphism σ:L≃L\sigma: L \simeq Lσ:L≃L such that σ(y)=x\sigma(y) = xσ(y)=x. This means xxx and yyy are Galois conjugates, with the roles of xxx and yyy reversed.

@Eric Wieser One thing to note here is that we support more informative docstrings than mathlib. You may have noticed that many statements in mathlib have very short, or even no docstrings. This may confuse new members. Lean Finder will provide more detailed descriptions for all statements, which I have now put into the spoiler.
it feels like your queries are LLM-generated, is there a specific algorithm you used? is this available in Leanfinder? Leansearch also features an LLM feature called "augmentation"

@Kenny Lau Thanks!
You don't need to use LLM to augment your query.

Quantitatively, Lean Finder achieves higher retrieval rates on mathlib4 than Lean Search, even with their "augmentation" feature:

  • LeanSearch: 0.487
  • Lean Finder: 0.620

Below I am using another query, which came from a vote submitted by an active user.
@leanfinder Theorem to show that if n is a positive integer, then 1/n is positive

Here’s what I found:

lemma (score: 0.700)

For any element aaa in a type with a multiplication operation and a partial order, if a>0a > 0a>0, then for all natural numbers nnn, the power ana^nan is also positive, i.e., an>0a^n > 0an>0. This is established by induction: for n=0n = 0n=0, a0=1>0a^0 = 1 > 0a0=1>0; for n+1n + 1n+1, an+1=an⋅a>0a^{n+1} = a^n \cdot a > 0an+1=an⋅a>0 since both an>0a^n > 0an>0 and a>0a > 0a>0.

succ_ge_zero(k (score: 0.699)

For any natural number kkk, the reciprocal of k+1k+1k+1 is positive in the real numbers, i.e., 1k+1>0\frac{1}{k+1} > 0k+11​>0. This follows from the fact that the successor of a natural number is always positive, and thus its reciprocal is also positive.

Nat.cast_pos (score: 0.699)

For any ordered semiring α\alphaα that is nontrivial (i.e., contains at least two distinct elements), and any natural number nnn, the cast of nnn in α\alphaα is positive (i.e., 0<(n:α)0 < (n : \alpha)0<(n:α)) if and only if 0<n0 < n0<n in N\mathbb{N}N.

More Retrievals...

Nat.one_div_pos_of_nat (score: 0.697)

For any natural number nnn and any linear ordered semifield α\alphaα, the reciprocal of the cast of nnn plus one is positive, i.e., 0<1n+10 < \frac{1}{n + 1}0<n+11​ where nnn is interpreted in α\alphaα.

[high]](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/find/?pattern=Int.natCast_pos#doc) (score: 0.697)

For any natural number nnn, the integer cast of nnn is positive if and only if nnn is positive, i.e., (0:Z)<n↔0<n(0 : \mathbb{Z}) < n \leftrightarrow 0 < n(0:Z)<n↔0<n.

lemma (score: 0.697)

For any element aaa in a type G0G_0G0​, the inverse a−1a^{-1}a−1 is positive if and only if aaa is positive. That is, 0<a−1↔0<a0 < a^{-1} \leftrightarrow 0 < a0<a−1↔0<a. This relies on the involutive property of inversion and the reflection of strict order under left multiplication by nonnegative elements.

add_one_pos (score: 0.693)

For any natural number nnn, adding one to nnn results in a number greater than zero, i.e., 0<n+10 < n + 10<n+1. This follows from the fact that the successor of any natural number is positive.

Nat.one_div_cast_pos (score: 0.692)

For any natural number n≠0n \neq 0n=0 and any ordered semifield α\alphaα, the reciprocal of the cast of nnn in α\alphaα is positive, i.e., 0<1(n:α)0 < \frac{1}{(n : \alpha)}0<(n:α)1​.

pow_pos (score: 0.692)

This is proven by induction: the base case n=0n = 0n=0 follows from a0=1>0a^0 = 1 > 0a0=1>0, and the inductive step uses an+1=an⋅aa^{n+1} = a^n \cdot aan+1=an⋅a and the positivity of aaa and ana^nan.
